question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
Simplify
\[\sin 70^\circ \cos 50^\circ + \sin 260^\circ \cos 280^\circ.\]
inference:
Using the sum-to-product formulas for sine and cosine, we have:
\[\begin{aligned}
\sin 70^\circ \cos 50^\circ + \sin 260^\circ \cos 280^\circ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin (70^\circ - 50^\circ) + \sin (70^\circ + 50^\circ) \right] + \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin (260^\circ - 280^\circ) + \sin (260^\circ + 280^\circ) \right] \\\
&= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 120^\circ \right] + \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin (-20^\circ) + \sin 540^\circ \right] \\\
&= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin 20^\circ + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right] + \frac{1}{2} \left[ -\sin 20^\circ + 0 \right] \\\
&= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}.
\end{aligned}\]
Final Answer: \boxed{$\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}$}. I hope it is correct.
ground_truth:
We have that $\sin 70^\circ = \cos 20^\circ,$ $\sin 260^\circ = -\sin 80^\circ = -\cos 10^\circ,$ and $\cos 280^\circ = \cos 80^\circ = \sin 10^\circ,$ so
\[\sin 70^\circ \cos 50^\circ + \sin 260^\circ \cos 280^\circ = \cos 20^\circ \cos 50^\circ - \sin 10^\circ \cos 10^\circ.\]Then by product-to-sum,
\begin{align*}
\cos 20^\circ \cos 50^\circ - \sin 10^\circ \cos 10^\circ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 70^\circ + \cos 30^\circ) - \frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 \sin 10^\circ \cos 10^\circ \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cos 70^\circ + \frac{1}{2} \cos 30^\circ - \frac{1}{2} \sin 20^\circ \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cos 30^\circ = \boxed{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}}.
\end{align*}

question:
Using the sum-to-product formulas for sine and cosine, we have:
\[\begin{aligned}
\sin 70^\circ \cos 50^\circ + \sin 260^\circ \cos 280^\circ &= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin (70^\circ - 50^\circ) + \sin (70^\circ + 50^\circ) \right] + \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin (260^\circ - 280^\circ) + \sin (260^\circ + 280^\circ) \right] \\\
&= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin 20^\circ + \sin 120^\circ \right] + \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin (-20^\circ) + \sin 540^\circ \right] \\\
&= \frac{1}{2} \left[ \sin 20^\circ + \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2} \right] + \frac{1}{2} \left[ -\sin 20^\circ + 0 \right] \\\
&= \frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}.
\end{aligned}\]
Final Answer: \boxed{$\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}$}. I hope it is correct.
There might be an error in the solution above because of lack of understanding of the question. Please correct the error, if any, and rewrite the solution. Only output the final solution \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
ground_truth:
We have that $\sin 70^\circ = \cos 20^\circ,$ $\sin 260^\circ = -\sin 80^\circ = -\cos 10^\circ,$ and $\cos 280^\circ = \cos 80^\circ = \sin 10^\circ,$ so
\[\sin 70^\circ \cos 50^\circ + \sin 260^\circ \cos 280^\circ = \cos 20^\circ \cos 50^\circ - \sin 10^\circ \cos 10^\circ.\]Then by product-to-sum,
\begin{align*}
\cos 20^\circ \cos 50^\circ - \sin 10^\circ \cos 10^\circ &= \frac{1}{2} (\cos 70^\circ + \cos 30^\circ) - \frac{1}{2} \cdot 2 \sin 10^\circ \cos 10^\circ \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cos 70^\circ + \frac{1}{2} \cos 30^\circ - \frac{1}{2} \sin 20^\circ \\
&= \frac{1}{2} \cos 30^\circ = \boxed{\frac{\sqrt{3}}{4}}.
\end{align*}
